Technology: ‚Ä¢ Fission: technology already established / Fusion: technology not yet established 4 x B1 ALLOW 1 mark for basic comparison within each consideration if no other marks are awarded. H556/02 Mark Scheme June 2023 Question Answer Mark Guidance Reaction: ‚Ä¢ Fission: chain reaction self -sustaining once initiated ‚Ä¢ Fusion: very high temperatures /pressures /amounts of energy required to initiate and continue reaction / challenges with storage and containment of plas ma Fuel: ‚Ä¢ Fission: f inite amount of uranium / needs to be enriched ‚Ä¢ Fusion: (unlimited) fuel available from (sea) water Waste: ‚Ä¢ Fission: Produces highly / high level / long half - life / long storage time radioactive waste ‚Ä¢ Fusion: Produces (effectively) no radioactive waste (products) / only radioactive material in contained in the reactor Safety: ‚Ä¢ Fission: Possibility of serious accident / leakage of radioactive material / ‚Äúmeltdown‚Äù AND/OR Fusion: very unlikely to produce serious accident (due to near instant shut down of reaction) / no leakage of radioactive material ALLOW hydrogen is easier to source (than uranium) for

q.t: In an experiment a circuit is set up so that a capacitor with a resistor in series can be charged and at some later time discharged through the same resistor without changing the positions of the components. This process can be repeated. The supply has a potential difference (p.d.) 6.0 V d.c.The capacitor has capacitance 1.0 ¬µF. The resistor has resistance 10 kŒ©.A voltmeter is used to measure the p.d. across the capacitor.

p.t: Draw a circuit diagram for this experiment. (b) Calculate the charge Q stored on the capacitor when it is fully charged. Q = C
Use a calculation to explain why it will not be possible to measure the variation of p.d. across the capacitor with time, using a stop watch
State how this experiment can be modified to measure the variation of p.d. across the capacitor with time as the capacitor charges
The capacitor was completely charged and then discharged to 4.12 V.
Calculate the time t required for the p.d. across the capacitor to reach 4.12 V when discharging. t = s
Calculate the average rate at which energy is lost by the capacitor as it discharges from 6.0 V to 4.12 V. average rate at which energy is lost = J s ‚Äì1

q.t: Radiographers commonly use molecules containing fluorine F-18 as tracers in positron emission tomography (PET) scanning. Fluorine has a proton number of 9. F-18 decays to oxygen (O) by Œ≤+ decay.

p.t: Write the equation for the decay of a nucleus of F-18 using nuclear notation.
The Œ≤+ particle (positron) produced travels only a short distance in the patient before it meets an electron and is annihilated. Calculate the wavelength Œª of gamma photons produced. Œª = m
X-rays and gamma-rays are produced by different physical processes. Briefly describe both processes
F-18 has a half-life of 109.7 minutes. Explain the advantage that this has for the patient but the disadvantage that this has for the radiographers
